THE POLICE OF BERLIN. The capital of the German Empire is one of the best ordered cities in the world in regard to its police. In point of numbers the force is consider- ably larger, regard being had to relative population, than our London City and Metropolitan police com- bined. That is to say, if the proportion of constables for inhabitants were as large here as it is in Berlin, we should have in London and its suburbs about 20,000, whereas the actual strength of the united forces is but about 15,000. It is often complained that the organisation of our Metropolitan police is too military, but the police of Berlin is in the most literal sense an army. Every one of the 3500 ordinary constables has been a non-commissioned officer, who must have served nine years with the colours. Appoint- ment to the police is the reward of exemplary conduct, and great care is taken in selecting the most deserving men. Whatever objection there may be to this mode of recruiting the force, it does effectually secure that no man shall obtain a place in it who is not of long tried character, and such difficulties as must occa- sionally arise from the inexperience of young and im- perfectly trained men, are avoided. It is not sur- prising that a force thus composed should be popular with the citizens, though, as might be expected from his antecedents, the Berlin policeman is apt to exer- cise authority with a brusqueness which would hardly be tolerated in London. A writer in the Journal des Debate, who has had the advantage of interviewing the President of Police, Baron Richtoffen, states that the force is not only composed of old soldiers, but is officered upon strictly military lines. It has at its head a colonel, and there are 11 captains, 93 lieutenants, and a proportionate number of non-commissioned officers. There are 61 districts, and at the head of each is a lieutenant, who has under him two non-commissioned officers, two telegraphists, two clerks, 12 ordinary constables, and one detective. The police captain exercises juris- diction over several districts, which are united into one division. The ordinary constables are only on their beats in the day-time. At night the safety of the capital is confided to a special body of night- watchmen, 500 in number, who wear a special uniform, are armed with a sabre, and provided with a whistle. They go on duty at ten o'clock, and re- main ont nLtil five or six in the morning, later in the winter than in the summer months. It may be added that 50 constables are mounted, against a total of about 250 in our own Metropolitan force. The colonel in command is not the President of the Police, but merely the first subordinate of that im- portant functionary. Baron Richtoffen has under hia charge, besides the police in the most restricted sense of the term—the Schutzleute, or ordinary street con- stables-the detective force, and the sanitary service, the officers entrusted with the surveillance of roads and buildings, markets, and hackney carriages, and the police des mceurs. He is the medium of communi- cation between the central Government and the municipality, which shares with the State the CGst of the whole organisation. The town finds the uniform of >he constables, and provides the station-houses, while the Government pays the wages. It is the same with the firemen, who are under the orders of the Police President. The detec- tive branch of the Berlin police is very completely organised. Count Plucker is at the head of this de- partment, and he has charge also of the police da 'iiitrnrs. He has been invested with the lattor responsi- bility of his own representation that the relations of the immoral and criminal classes are such as to require their being supervised by the same official. But the two forces remain separate in organisation, though united under a single chief. For detective purposes, the town is parcelled out into eight divisions, each under the direction of a superior officer of the department. The detectives, of course, wear no uniform, but they carry a revolver. This has only been permitted quite recently in consequence of some dangerous strugglos which have occurred with prisoners, and the officers are strictly enjoined to uee the weapon only in the last resort. The division of labour among the members of the detective force corresponds with that which prevails among the criminal classes. Most people know that professional criminals are every- where divided as strictly as the votaries of honest labour. A pickpocket, for example, would not under- take a burglary, and a professed cracksman would not lay himself out to practice the confidence trick. Every organised form of crime in the German capital is con- fronted by an officer who has given special attention to it, is familiar, more or less, with those who habitually practise it, and well acquainted with their modes of working. This division of labour is the principle upon which the Berlin criminal album has been arranged. The portraits of pickpockets form one series of photographs, those of housebreakers a second, those of known swindlers a third. If a person entered a police-station covnplaining that his pocket- handkerchief had been stolen, the album of known pickpockets would be brought out for his inspection, and he would be asked to identify the robber. It very often happens, as might be imagined, that the victim of a theft has not taken notice enough to enable him to do this with certainty, but his impres- sions are often sufficiently strong to set a sharp de- tective on a search for the right man. The special functions of the police des vuvurs cannot be described in detail. They are exercised, however, with a great deal of rigour. All public balls and public-house concerts must be closed at midnight, and other regulations in the interest of morality are very strictly enforced. One of the very numerous and diversified functions of the police in Berlin is the provision of night shelter for casuals. The accom- modat.ion, however, leaves a go-ld deal to be desired. When the refuge is full, as it usually is on a winter night, there is no room for the inmates to lie down; at no time is there any resting place but bare boards. Homeless wanderers are received for shelter up to two o'clock in the morning. Shelter is literally all that they obtain, and the atmosphere is so bad from overcrowding that they run no inconsiderable risk of suffocation or blood poisoning. The casual is not allowed, however, to avail himself of even this miserable refuge for more than three nighta in suc- cession, except at the risk of being prosecuted as a vagabond. Common humanity might seem to dictate a reformation here, but it is alleged that if more comfortable quarters were provided, the nightly refuge would become too attractive. The arrange- ments for the casual poor will, however, hardly be pointed to as one of the brightes"; features in the gene- rally admirable Berlin system of police.

THE RECALL OF SIR DRUMMOND WOLFF: The news, says the Jforning Post, that Sir Henry Drummond Wolff has been summoned to London to report personally to her Majesty's Government on the progress of his mission, and to confer with them re- specting the negotiations which he is carrying on with the Turkish Commissioner in Egypt, is a clear indi- cation that the Government are resolved to resume wish energy the work of Egyptian reorganisation, which was greatly interrupted while the Liberal Ad- ministration was in office. Although Mr. Gladstone's Government fully recognised the opportunity and the importance of Sir H. D. Wolff's mission, no instruc- tions of any importance were transmitted to him during a lengthened period. There is n-) foun- dation for the report that Sir II. D. Wolff has been summoned to London, with the object of entrusting him with a special mission to Constan- tinople. The report has perhaps arisen from the fact that, previous to the nomination of Sir William White as Ambassador to the Porte, the idea of appointing Sir H. D. Wolff to that post had been entertained in Government circles. We understand that the British Commissioner at Cairo is likewise expected to furnish Lord Iddesleigh with further and more direct infor- mation regarding Ismail Pasha's claims, and more especially on the impediments which prevent his ap- pealing to any tribunal. It certainly appears mon- strous that in a country over which we indisputably exercise a certain amount of influence, an Egyptian, simply because he has been the ruler of the country, should find it impossible to enjoy the privileges ac- corded to the lowest fellah in submitting his claims to any tribunal. We understand that the Government fully realise the injustice of the case, and are anxious that the affair should not become more serious than it is already.

EPITOME OF NEWS. BRITISH AND FOREIGN. An old man named William Oook was burned to death at Southsea whilst reading in bed. Eight persons have been buried by a landslip near Fmbrun, in the South of France. By a fire at a house in Grigg-street, Portsmouth, a feeble old man, who slept on tLe ground floor, was burned to death. Another arrest of Anarchists has taken place at Frankfort-on-the-Maine. Burglars broke into the Theatre Royal, Sunderland, the other night, and made off with jewellery and other articles belonging to several actors, to the value of about JE10. Further details of the floods in Southern Europe state that the railway line between Genoa and Yenti- miglia has suffered so severely that it will take more than a month before it can be opened. The Earl of Enniskillen died at his residence, Florence-court, county Fermanagh. He is succeeded by his eldest son, Viscount Oole, who represented Enniskillen in the Parliament of 1880. The North of England Seamen's and Firemen's Friendly Society at North and South Shields have passed resolutions asking the shipowners to pay the same rate of wages on the Tyne as are paid at other ports. The Royal Commission on the Land Acts formed two courts at Killarney to expedite the business there. Lords Cowper and Milltown acted as the respective chairmen. Witnesses were examined as to the com- bination to resist the enforcement of legal obligations, and as to what extent a general desire existed among tenants to avail themselves of the provisions of the Act. A carman, who pleaded ignorance of London regula- tions, as he was fresh from the country, in reply to a charge of obstruction, was let off with a fine of 2s. at the City Summons Court. He expressed surprise at the result thus: Two bob for that I'll have to go without grub to-day for that." Alfred William Ayres, an engineer, of 28, Oampden. street, Notting-hill-gate, cut his throat with a razor. He exclaimed to his landlord," Go away, Dad," and fell dead on the floor; A letter, apparently written by a lady, was found in his room. Jealousy is supposed to be the cause. r William Hammersley, 21, a notorious shopbreaker, who has been several times convicted at Nottingham and other places, was charged at Leicester on Monday,, with breaking into the house of Thomas Nutting, and stealing several pounds' worth of property. Nutting, who was sentenced last week to 20 years' penal servi- tude for burglary, was a companion of Hammersley, and when Nutting's friecds were absent at the trial Hammersley perpetrated the robbery. He was com- mitted for trial at the assizes. At Rowley, whilst two|chartermasters, named Daniel and Dan Gill, father and son, were inspecting the workings, with naked light., at Warren's Half Colliery, an explosion of gas occurred, and both men were shockingly injured. An unmarried lady, named Jessie Susan Lock, 37, of Dorchester, fell over the High Tor Rock at Matlock Bath, sustaining injuries which an hour later termi- nated fatally. A fire broke out on Mosday on Lord Salisbury's estate, Great Hadham. A boy in a house upset a paraffin lamp, and in a few moments the building was in flames, which spread to an adjoining cottage: The fire raged for several hours, the property being completely destroyed. Six whales were seen in the English Channel on Monday morning half a mile off Sandgate. The Corporation of New Romney have resolved to make an experiment in the granting of allotments to agricultural labourers. It has been decided to set aside 9A acres of land, 20 perches to be allotted to each ap- 2 plicant. The Canterbury Fishing Protection Association have decided to restock the River Stour with young trout, so ai to provide better sport for anglers next season. It is proposed to purchase a stock ot the Loch Leven trout." The Rev. George Brown, who was appointed vicar of London by the Queen in 1840, died on Saturday. The value of the living is JE300 a year. Tin Buckrose election petition is fixed for tri Sat Driffield on the 6th December, before Baron Pollock end Mr. Justice Smith. The rivet-makers in the Staffordshire districts who turned out on strike a week ago for an advance of wages resumed work on Monday at the old rates. Near Listowel the other night a police patrol met a man named Scanlan carrying a gun. He fired at the police, and they attempted to swim across the river but, after a desperate struggle in the water, Scanlan was arrested. A miner named William Furze, aged 19, while at work in the Levant Mine, Penzance, 1000 feet below the bed of the ocean, was hastily warned to avoid an impending blast of a lode, and in moving away he fell to the bottom of a 70 feet hole and broke his neck. Alderman R. Renner, Deputy Mayor of Queea* borough, was found dead in bed on Monday morning. At Marlborough-street Police-court, London, Samuel Schneider, of Cross-street, Soho, was fined 10s. and costs for assaulting Isaac Julius, of 13, Broad-street, by cutting off the end of the latter's moustache, of which he was very proud, and which a moment before had been pronounced very nice by a lady. The Agricultural Deputies have addressed to the Government a protest against the continuation of the prohibition to import French cattle into England. They say that the disease has disappeared long since, and the prohibition is unnecessary and prejudicial to their interests. It is stated that the Council of the Liberty and Property Defence League have resolved to extend their operations among the wording classes in order to counteract the influence of the Socialists. In the annual report of the Commissioner in charge of the Woods and Royal Forests, it is stated that the continued depression in agriculture and the stagnation in mining enterprise have considerably affected the Crown revenues, and rendered it necessary to grant allowances and reductions of rent to many of the Grown tenants of b,)th lands and mines Nevertheless, the net payments into the Exchequer bad been maintained during the past year at the same sum as during each of the four previous years. The Prince of Wales received at Sandringham on' Monday two large deputations of London workmen, who thanked his Royal Highness for his successful efforts in enabling the artisans of the metropolis to attend the Exhibition at a cheap rate of admission. Addrepses were presented from the London Trades Council and the London Working Men's Association; and the Piicce in his replies referred to the extra- ordinary success which had attended the scheme, more than a million persons having been benefited by it. The members cf the two deputations were introduced to the Princess of Wales and the young Princesses, and after beiDg entertained at luncheon, were shown over the hall and estate, and returned to town in the evening by special trains. While the Lords of the Admiralty were on a visit to Haulbowline on Monday for the purpose of inspecting the new naval docks in progress there, a deputation from Queerstown waited upon them, praying that the original plan may not be departed from, and that the second dry dock may be constructed as at first pro- posed, so that a large number of workmen may not be thrown out of employment Lord George Hamilton, in reply, said the works at present determined on would provide for the continuance in employment for at least another year of those now engaged, and as there were signs of reviralof trade he hoped the country would rise from the depression from which it had long suf- fered Dr. Tindal Robinson on Monday night accepted the invitation of the Brighton Conservatives to be the candidate of the party for the existing vacancy in the representation of the borough. In his address he avows himself a progressive Conservative, in entire sympathy with the views recently enunciated by Lord Randolph Churchill and the Marquis of Salisbury. Four thousand children, it is estimated, were refused admission to Board Schools throughout the metro- polis on Monday on the ground that their fees had not been paid. Josiah Brett, horse trainer, and Alfred Laloubere, otherwise Count Laloubere, were tried at Liverpool Assizes, on Monday, os the charge of conspiring, with a third person, who has absconded, to defraud the clerk of the course and the stewards of Kelso Steeplechases of large sums of money. The fraud consisted in enter- ing and running as a maiden a horse which had, in fact, won many races. Both were found guilty, and Brett was sentenced to a year's and Laloubere to three month's imprisonment. Speaking at Hoxne, Mr. Arch said that the Agricul' tural Labourers' Union would soon be engaged in drawing up a political programme, and the first itero in it would be renewed confidence in the Grand Old Man and Home Rule for Ireland. The next election would be a savage fiqht, and the Tories would come down with a crash. The death is announced of M. Textoris, the den of Paris stockbrokers, at the advanced age of 83. M. Tex- toris was well-known in the London financial circle of the last generation. He had lately retired from active business, and died at his chateau in Burgundy. M'. The Rev. O. Shaw, of Dundee, has received a letter from Sir Henry Pcnsonby, stating that the Queen will be happy to give a donation of fcl5 to the memorial to King Alexander III. of Scotland, to be erected on the spot where the King was killed, between Kinghorn and Burntisland, in Fifo. An agitation is being promoted in Halifax against the action of the Canadian Government in subsidising ocean mail steamers having their terminus in American territory. A deputation has left for Ottawa to ask the Government only to grant a subsidy to slearr ers making Halifax and St John their winter termini instead ot Halifax and Portland. JEM STATMAN was found and returned from Birming- ham, looking none the more healthy or reputable for his carouse, to take up his place by the bedside of the still insensible Jack Blogg, and doggedly refuse all offers of assistance in his task. Will he live ?" he asked the doctor, almost fiercely. I'm afraid not," that gentleman replied. •' If ever he wakes to consciousness at all—which is more than doubtful-it will only be at the end." So that he can speak half a dozen words to me it will be sufficient. I ask no more," said Jem, in a low, concentrated tone. And to make sure, in such a contingency, that he should not lose the chance of hearing such words, if they were spoken, Jem Statman never left the house for a moment. The detective paid him a visit, but departed as much in the dark as he 'ivl been before. Je n either could not—or would not—tell him any. thing that was of the lea3t service. Several days passed, and still the boy lingered on in his death-like insensibility to all that Was passing around him. From the Grange came down daily hampers of delicate food and wines, which were sent by lieryl with many anxious enquiries aa to Jack Blogg's state, all of which were received by the surly denizen of the Rookery with scant thanks. The doctor was the only person admitted to the cottage, and he remonstrated with Statman. They are all very kind to y.m," he said, and deserve a little more civility at your hands, I think. Do you ?" returned Jem Statman, with a strange, fierce light in his eyes. "Maybe so—at any rate, don't be afraid but I shall pay all my debts in full." "At any rate," said the doctor, not quite under- standing this speech—" I think that you are bound to let Mr. Atherstone in. You may not pay much heed to religion yourself, but think what that poor lai might crave after, if he was sensible." 011, if that's all, I'm no ways particular," was the surly response. "Let the parson come and lalk religion over him if he pleases. 'Twon't do Jack much harm nor much good neither, if it comes to that, seeing as how he can't hear it, let alone understtnd." Miss Atherstone has been very kind in sending all these little luxuries," the doctor went on. "I sup- pose I had better tea her how grateful you are for them." Oh, ay Tell her that, if you like," responded Jem, with a short, difagreeable laugh. Give her my humble dooty, and all the rest of it. Of course, I'm much beholden to her—and so is Jack, there—though it's all one to him now whether there's lots to eat and drink, or nothing. You may tell her, too," he con- tinued, after they ggt outside the door—for in the cottage they had been speaking only in subdued whispers. "\ou may tell her this from me—Jem Statman—that I am as sure as that there is a sun in the sky yonder of one thing." And tiat is ?" As my boy-Ieastways, the boy as is all the same to me as my own—isn't a-going to leave the world so quiet as everybody seems to think. I don't want to insult you, sir you've been very kind to—to him -and God bless you for it! if I may pray so; but you don't feel as I do." p And you think that he will recover ?" I think as how he'll wake up for long enough to tell me all I want to know," was the dogged answer. "And that's who has sent him to his death." I hope you may be right, my friend. But I very much doubt it." "It'll b2 so, for all that," persisted Jem, in a tone of settled conviction that the doctor thought it would be hopeless to attempt to combat. He loved me, you see, for all my rough ways, and I loved him the same, after my fashiun. You can tell Miss Atherstone this, sir, and say as how she may send what she likes—I ain't above taking it-not I!—but don't let her be a-coming near my place—that's all." Which message reached Beryl-in a much milder form, however; though, modified as it was, its in- solence made both her and her friends very angry, showing AS it did, with what an ill grace her favours had been received. And so the days wore on, bringing no change to Jack Blogg, who still lay in the state of lethargy caused by the wound on the temple. It was this in- sensibility that kept him alive, the doctor said. Nature was completely at rest in his case, and it was impossible now to say how much longer he might last. There was another event, too, which every suc- ceeding day brought nearer now—Beryl's wedding- which would shortly take place in the same old church where her grandfather and his father before him had stood at the altar with their brides. There were to be all sorts of rejoicings in the neigh- bourhood, for, besides the large party of aristocratic friends invited to the ceremony itself, the tenants were to be feasted in a large marquee erected in the grounds, and the Sunday-school children decorated and dressed for the occasion. Indeed, Beryl Atherstone was sparing neither ex- pense nor trouble to make her last appearance as her own mistress as effective as possible, even to ordering the major part of her trousseau in Leamington instead of sending to London for it, thereby gladdening the hearts of the tradespeople who received her instruc- tions. Mr. Carson had got his orders, and completed the necessary papers, so there was no occasion for hirr to be so frequently at the Grange; and, truth to tell, for many reasons he avoided being there any oftener than he could help, now, though he could hardly have told what those reasons were, had he been pressed ever so hard. Indeed, he confessed as much to Noel, when that young gentleman, who passed all his days now in a seventh heaven of delight, taxed his old friend with avoiding them. "Xo j you must not think that, Noel," returned the lawyer, in a grave, halii-absent tone. But I have been so much occupied lately that, upon my word-" "Yes—yes—of course hastily interrupted Noel. I was only joking but I'm not joking when I say that in my opinion Graham is not using me kindly. I expected him here long since." Ah, Noel, you must not be vexed with him, nor doubt his friendship for you. The day will come when you will know him better." Nonsense As if I didn't, know him well enough already," replied the young man, heartily. I don t doubt Graham's friendliness, Mr. Carson. I only think that lie is enjoying himself in town, and doesn't care to leave it. I was vexed with him more on Lily's account than my own, believe me. But I suppose, as she is satisfied, I have no right to be otherwise." Wise judges are we of each other," ironically ob- serves the poet. If Noel Atherstone could but have seen his friend just then, have known the tortures of doubt and hesitation that racked his mind, he would not have accused him, even in jest, of seeking his own gratification by remaining in London when he would so much rather have spent the time by the side of his betrothed bride. He made up for his absence, certainly, by the length and frequency of his letters to Lillian, though they were not the most cheerful epistles; and he avoided all mention of the forthcoming event at the Grange in so marked a manner that his fiancee, whose answers were invariably filled with the subject, could i not not help observing it, and once, in a conversation with Beryl, rather incautiously let fall the fact. "It's of no consequence, Lily, dear," replied the heiress, with a sweet smile that concealed a- slightly malevolent expression in her eyes. Graham Carson doesn't like me, I know, but the world is wide enough for both of us." Not like ycu Oh, Beryl!" cried Lillian, in distress. It's quite true, though you pretend to be shocked at it, you little hypocrite," laughed Beryl. And there's nothing particularly surprising in the fact, either. I am only sorry for it because, as a good wife, you will be bound to contract a little wholesome dis- like of your husband's aversion, and I should have preferred your continuing to love me." "You need not be afraid of that, Beryl," exclaimed the girl. If Graham rcally is so unjust to you— though I think you must be mistaken—he will not at- tempt to make me the same." And then the subject dropped, Beryl Atherstone not caring sufficiently either for Graham's likes or dis- likes to pursue it further. Indeed, she was much more troubled just now about a much more humble individual, who would not be persuaded to look upon her with favour, or accept her bounties in any but the most churlish spirit. She had distributed presents far and wide, till all tongues were loud in praise of her liberality, but with all around bowing down before her and ministering to her will, she could find no way of conciliating the inhabitant of the Rookery. The excitement created by the attack on Jack Blogg had partia'ly died away, though active enquiries were still going on respecting what was still as great a mystery as ever. Beryl had called more than once in her daily walks at the little desolate home where the boy lay in a state of insensibility to all aronnd him, but, though she would fain have gone in and looked upon him, Jem Statman would never admit her beyond the threshold. Not that he was actually rude in speech, or said in so many words that she should not enter, but that this was what he meant was sufficiently shown by the way in which he would stand in the doorway and never offer to move on one side till she had departed, as though he were watching over some precious thing he feared might be stolen from him. Outwardly he was civil to his benefactress, but there was no warmth in the coldly civil words with which, after a time, he acknowledged what she had brought or sent; and any little commonplace expres- sion of sympathy or regret for the sufferer that she uttered were received by Jem Statman without a syllable of thanks or acknowledgment of any sort. If I were you, Beryl," Lillian said to her, after one of these visits, at which she had been present, I would not trouble myself any further about the man. He's a bear." \ay—perhapa that is doing him injustice," Beryl replied. He is not polite, certainly; but remember the circumstances. People of his class are often re- served, and ashamed to let their emotion be seen, while the only way of hiding them is by affecting a brusquerie that may be easily mistaken for rudeness. Lillian thought there was scarcely sufficient occasion for so elaborate an apology, though she could not con- tradict her friend, even while she wondered inwardly why Beryl, who was generally so imperious in her manner, submitted to the rebuffs she did in this instance. Certainly, Jem Statman was hardly more polite to others than he was to the heiress. Kough and morose in manner, careless and deficient of anything like af- fection to his companion as he had usually appeared, the care he now exhibited for the stricken lad was more like that of some wild animal for its young than that of a reasoning being. It was as though he were afraid of some hidden enemy-jealous of anyone even looking at the boy besides himself. The doctor, of course, he could not keep away, but even his ministrations were regarded with ill-concealed disfavour, and, though he had given a reluctant assent to the rector's visits, he showed plainly enough that he would much rather have been without them. Indeed, he said as much on one occasion. I don't know what you expect to do, coming here," he said, in a sullen tone. What's tho use 0' coming and praying and preaching over one as can't hear you, and wouldn't understand it if he could ?" It is my duty, as a minister of the Gospel that you would do well to read yourself, replied Mr. Ather- stone, rather severely, for the man's manner was more than usually insolent this day. Bah!" mockingly sneered the man. I don't believe much in them sort o' things. If there's any truth in them, better keep 'em all for the big house up yonder, and those that lives in it. They might do no more good there than here, I'm thinking. Psalms and prayers is all very well in their way, but they won't heal the sick, or bring the dead back to life. If they'd make poor Jack there speak now, I'd believe some good on 'em." Mr. Atherstone attempted a few words of csnsola- tion to the man, passing over his bitterness of speech without any other notice, but Jem Statman showedno signs of being soothed by them, except that he was not quite so defiant in hin demeanour. I'm, maybe, a. bit hard, sir," he said, roughly. I've not been brought up in a genteel way, but I don't mean any ill will to you, for all that. You and jour good lady have been very good to me, and I sin n't forget it." Somebody else has been good to you as well, Stat- man," gently replied the rector. Ah, they all do their best in the village, I will say." I don't mean the villagers," continued Mr. Ather- stone. "Buta lady who need not allow you to stop here as you do, without let or hindrance. Miss Ather- stone is the mistress here." Ay, ay so it is," said Jem, with a short laugh. And it's you who ought to be master this very hour. And when I look there, at that poor lad lying so still and pale-one as I love like my own flesh and blood-dying like a dog, just acause he knowed a secret as had murder and mischief in it, I'm a'most tempted to shorten the time.' Mr. Atherstone looked at him as though he thcught the man had taken leave of his senses. "J don't think you quite know what you're talking about, Statman," lie said, kindly. Leastways, if I did, it would only be talking without any proofs. But I've heard all about old Squire Atherstone's will, sir." His will! THE COLSTON FESTIVAL. FOR M. HICKS-BEACH ON IRELAND. The dinner of the Dolphin Society, in celebration of the Colston Anniversary, was held on Saturday night in the Victoria Rooms, Bristol. About 3UO gentlemen were present. Mr. G. W. Edwaia* occupied the chair. Among the guests were Sir M. Hicks-Beach, M.P., the Lord Advocate, Mr. W. Long, M.P., Colonel Hill, M.P., Mr. Whitmore. M.P., Mr. Llewellyn, M.P., Mr. J. W. Plunkett, M.P. Replying to the toast of her Majesty's Ministers, Sir M. Hicks-Beach, who was received with en- thusiasm, said he hoped the Government had some- what of the confidence and trust of their fellow- countrymen in what was a greater difficulty than any in Burinah, Bulgaria, or Egypt, because it was nearer home, and that was in their dealings with the affairs of Ireland. He felt deeply the ditlicultv and the re- sponsibility of that work, but he thought that in doing it -in attempting to do it, at least-he had the sympathy of his fellow- countrymen. (Hear, hear.) He knew that he had the sympathy of his constituents. (Loud cheers.) Administration was his main work in Ireland at the present moment. (Hear, hear.; He confessed in his humble judgment that the country bad suffered largely in the past from the hot and cold fito, so to ipeak, of the Government of the day—(hear, be3r)- and that he thought that much might be done in Ireland by quiet, steady, constitutional administra- tion of the law as they found it. (Hear, hear.) His hearers might say that ought to be an easy task. It was not an easy task at the present moment. (Hear, hear.) He had wondered since he bad been in Ire- land at the loyalty and devotion with which the per- manent officials of all grades in the country per- formed their duty to the State. (Cheers.) It was immensely to their credit that they had resisted temptation, and that in spite of discouragement they had remained loyal and true in their duty to the Queen. (Applause.) Then there was another thing to be remembered in the great speech in which Mr. Gladstone introduced his un- happy measure. He spoke of the legislation of the Imperial Parliament as never having satisfied Ireland, because it bad a foreign origin. He believed the fact was that to too many Irishmen the law had seemed a foe because they had no confidence in i's administra- tion. He believed that if it were possible, as he thought it was, to wipe away the effect of the introduction of the Home Rule Bill, both on the official mind and the people at large, to infuse fresh vigour and firm- ness in the administration, to teach the people that in Ireland as in England the reiga of law meant the reign of justice to rich and poor alike, that the rights of the poor man as well as the rich would be re- spected, and that the law should never be used a3 an instrument of oppression-he believed that if these lessons could be taught to the Irish people the victory would be won. (Applause.) They would remember that in the short session of Parliament Mr. Parnelland his lieutenant, Mr. Gladstone—laughter)—pressed upon the House of Commons a measure which practi- cally would have reduced all the judicial rents of Ireland by 50 per cent., on the ground, as was alleged, that a fall in the prices of produce made it impossible for the tenants of Ireland to pay those rents. They would remember that her Majesty's Government had felt it to be their duty to oppose the proposal as being based on no sufficient ground, but that at the same time they stated their intention of inquiring how far the operation of the Land Act of 18SI was effected either by combination to resist payment of rent, or by a fall in the prices of produce, and how at the same time they argued that pending that inquiry, where it was necessary to reduce rents, landlords would be lenient to their tenants, and in a few cases of hardship the law courts had a right, as they had the power, to interfere. That was their argument. It was received with derision by the Home Rule party of Great Britain. They were told that her Majesty's Government were in a con- spiracy with the Irish landlords to evict wholesale the Irish tenantry. Well, what had happened ? The Irish landlords voluntarily, in large numbers, bad met their tenants with a generosity and liberality which could not be too highly prized. (Applause.) The County Courts had exercised their power under the law with fairness and with justice, and the Government had brought what pressure they could, acting always within the law, to bear upon those few landlords who would not follow the example of their more generous fellows. And in doing so he believed that they had acted in the interests of the landlords as well as of the tenants, for he was quite sure that there was no greater foe to the rights of property in the world than the man who attempted harshly to exact its rights, and failed to perform its duties. (Hear, bear.) Well, this had been what had occurred, and now, instead of being told that the Government were in a conspiracy with the Irish landlords to evict their tenants, they were told that they had exercised a dispensing power which they had never dreamed of exercising, because they had not the power to do it; and that, in the second place, they were carrying out the policy of the National League. Well, but what had been the result? The result bad been an evident improvement in the state of Ireland. (Cheers.) During the last six weeks outrages had diminished by half—(cheers)—compared with what they were in the previous six weeks, and there had arisen, owing to the action of the landlords, a better and more friendly feeling between their tenantry and themselves than bad existed in Ireland for many years past. Allud- ing to persons who had taken it upon themselves to go up and down the country and endeavour to excite the Irish tenants against their own inclinations, he said that if these counsels should unhappily prevail, if they took the advice that was so wickedly tendercd to them, the Government had but one duty—the law must be enforced—(prolonged cheers)—and with all the powers at the command of the Government; and if those powers were not sufficient, Parliament must be asked for more. (Cheers.) He would not conceal from them that he should make such a request to Parliament with a heavy heart. They were not going to compete with Mr. Gladstone on a Home Rule Bill for Ireland. (Loud cheers.) They would not so forget their principles, they would not so belie their promises—(cheers)—and, if there were any persons outside that room who imagined they bad no principles, and did not care for their promises, he would suggest even to them that there was one great reason why they should not compete with Mr. Glad- stone in that market, and that was because he would certainly outbid them. Sir Michael called attention to the Commissions of Inquiry the Government had issued, and continued They would endeavour to solve the great question of local government for Great Britain as well as for Ireland—(hear, hear)—for he began to think that hid hearers would remind him that there were other parts of the United Kingdom besides Ireland—(cheers)—that Parliament bad heard a great deal for the last twenty years upon the subject of Irish legislation, and that there were matters in England-perhaps even in the country called Scotland, which might require the attention of the House of Commons. Those followers of theirs who so patiently and so loyally supported the Govern- ment during the short session in August and Sep- tember would, he thought, agree with him that the first I requisite, reasonable, constitutional, and wise legislation was that the House of Commons should be enabled to do its business. (Hear, hear.) He had the best reason for stating to his hearers that this question—full as it was of the greatest difficulties in its practical solution—was engaging the most anxious and careful attention of the Government; but her Majesty's Government were not prepared in the early days of November with a complete plan which they hoped to submit to Parliament by the commencement of the next session. (Cheers.) Mr. Macdonald (Lord Advocate for Scotland) and Mr. Long (Secretary to the Local Government Board) responded for The Houses of Parliament." LORD HERSCHELL ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS. Lord Herschell was the principal guest at the annual dinner of the Anchor Society, held at the Grand Hotel. Mr. H. Daniel, the president of the society, was in the chair, and there were present Lord Ebrington, M.P., Mr. Summers, M.P., Mr. Winter- botham, M.P., Mr. Handel Cossham, M.P., Mr. Pitt- Lewis, M.P., and Mr. H. Hobhouse, M.P. Lord Herschell, responding for the Houses of Parliament, said the foreign politics of this country in respect to South-Eastern Europe were a subject upon which both political parties were agreed. Liberals welcomed the changed views of their political opponents as re- garded the situation in South-Eastern Europe, and they would rejoice to co-operate with them. What- ever might divide the Liberal party at the present time, all Liberals would agree that they were 11 not prepared to place unbounded confidence in the present leader of the Conservative party in the House of Commons. He (Lord Herschell) had no fault to find with the Chancellor ot the Exchequer's Dartford programme; his complaint was that if the programme was, as he believed it to bo, a good one, the Minister who announced it was more responsible than perhaps any other single individual for the fact that much of it was not already the law of the land. In the fore- front was placed reform of the procedure of the House of Commons. To represent this as a ques- tion upon which there was a difference of opinion amongst the Liberal leaders was utterly without foundation. When Mr. Gladstone was pleading for this very reform Lord R. Churchill was doing his best to prevent any rules that could be effec- tive from passing into law. But his views of obstruction in those days were, no doubt, very different from those which he enunciated now. (Hear, hear). Lord R. Churchill was vexed because it was said he had adopted the programme of the Liberal party and he had declared that it was not the programme of the Liberal party, but the pro- gramme of Lord Salisbury, as set forth in his speech at Newport last autumn. But events happened even before Lord Salisbury's speech at Newport. Lord Hartington, at Nelson, in the spring of 1882, submitted a programme which was very like the programme which Lord Randolph Churchill proclaimed the other day at Dartford. (Cheers.) Whatever might be the view of Liberals in regard to those who were advo- eating these reforms, they would do nothing to stand in the way of them. But there must be some watch- fulness with regard to the action of the leader of the House of Commons, as a new convert was prover- bially liable to run into extremes. They must see that the Chancellor of the Exchequer did not carry his re- forms too far. la reference to any reforms which might be proposed, let the Liberal party endeavour to make them such measures as they themselves would have passed. In regard to the difference of opinion which existed ill the Liberal party upon the Irish question, all Liberals were agreed that, however disgraceful the means by which the Act:of Union were brought aboal:, it would be neither right nor possible tç- revert to tb.3 state of things which existed before it waq pao«<>d. (Hear, bear.) They were all agreed that the results of the government of Ireland during this century bad been the reverse of satisfactory, and that it was de- sirable, as far as could be safely done, to do some- thing to satisfy that spirit of nationality in Ireland which cried out for an extension of the powers of self- government in that country. The English people were not bound wittingly to imperil their own safety for the purpose even of satisfying a sentiment of that kind, Adequate security should be afforded that those who were opposed to any change, and who would be affected by it, should be justly dealt with. He thought all would agreE; on these matters; where a difference of opinion arose was in the view which they took of the extent of the danger and what they might think safeguards against that danger; what they might think adequate security, and how that security was to be afforded. There was the seat of the difference. The difference was one rather of degree than of absolutely irreconcileable principle, and therefore, perhaps, the less impossible of a solution which should reconcile their conflicting views. (Cheers.) He would deprecate any attempt to patch up a hasty peace. He believed such a course would be unsuccessful. It harmony was to be re- stored, three things would be essential-patience, temper, and a free interchange of views and ho did not despair, if those conditions were honestly com- plied with, of seeing that harmony restored which hE believed would be the earnest desire of all of them (Cheers.) Lord Ebrington, Mr. Summers, and JJr. Pitt-Lewis also responded, and other toasts followed.

CONFERENCE of LIBERAL UNIONISTS. A conference of Unionists took place on Saturday afternoon at Nottingham, when representatives from all parts of the county assembled. The Duke of St. Albans presided, both at the meetings of the executive and of the general conference. The conference was called for the purpose of considering the past and future work of the Liberal Unionist Association, and the desirability of a separate organisation. The Marquis of Hartington was unable to attend, but the details of the scheme of organisation ultimately adopted had been approved by him. On the m )tion of Lord Belper, seconded by Mr. Grosvenor Hodgkinson (Newark), it was decided to form a divisional com- mittee in each Parliamentary division of the town and county. Colonel Seely. proposed that a central paid registration secretary and agent for the Unionist party, to assist in the general work of the association, be appointed for the town and county; and it was stated that at the registration courts and in all active political movements the Liberal L'nioniat Party will in future be separately and independently represented. Further resolutions, appointing not less than three delegates from each Parliamentary division of the town and county to attend the conference of the Central Association to be held in London en December 7, were passed.

THE BIRKBECK INSTITUTION. Speaking a. the 63rd anniversary of the Birkbeck Literary and Scientific Institution in London, Viscount Cranbrook, having distributed the prizes and certifi- cates to 800 successful students, said, after congratu- lating the institution upon attaining its grand climacteric," that it had fully justified the anticipa- tion of its founder of the wants which he believed to exist. When Mr. Birkbeck founded the institution in 1823 very little had been done except in elementary education. Practically nothing had been done in secondary education, which was that to which Mr. Birkbeck directed his attention, and he founded the institution in the faith that the need for it would be speedily shown. Lord Brougham had said that the demand preceded the supply. There were, however, certain things in which the supply must frequently precede the demand, and education was one of them. (Hear, hear.) It was to the highest credit of the Birkbeck Institution that it had never gone to the State to ask for public money, and he rejoiced that it had found tho Queen and Prince and Princesses taking that interest in it which they always took, as indi- viduals, in the State, feeling, as the Duke of Albany felt during his short life, that the advancement of the country in literary and intellectual education was such an iwportant matter that he devoted himself to the expansion of that education which he found existing at the Birkbeck Institution, and to which Le gave his support by laying its first stone. (Cheers.) A great deal was said in the present day of tbe education of the country and what was to be done, or not done, by the State. In spite of his friend Mr. Matthew Arnold, he strongly advised them in the matter of secondary education to be, as far as possible, inde- pendentof the State. (Cheers.) There was such a thing as being too dependent on the State. (Cheers.) What he believed had been the making of this country had been the independence of the people, their self-reli- ance, and self-education. (Cheers.) They did not want to make people all alike and in the same mould. He did not say, however, that it was not the interest of the State not to supplement—as in the case of elementary education what was done by individuals where it was clearly and palpably for the advance- ment of the whole nation. (Cheers.) He felt a deep interest in the education of the country and trusted to the energy that for 63 years bad carried on the in- stitution to the height at which it bad arrived, to maintain it for many years for the benefit of the people at large and to do honour to the country to which it belonged. (Cheers.)
